questions.question:
Question 1: A young woman delivered her baby on the way to the hospital. While examining her, you 
notice a perineal tear. This injury could have been prevented by all except:

options.c: Slow delivery of the head in between contractions

questions.explanation:
Perineal injury cannot be prevented in normal labor by routine timely episiotomy. Routine 
episiotomy is associated with an increased incidence of disruption of anal sphincters and rectal 
tears. Indications of episiotomy: • Shoulder dystocia • Breech delivery • Fetal macrosomia • Operative vaginal deliveries • Persistent occiput posterior positions Methods of prevention of perineal laceration: • Avoid delivery by early extension • Deliver head in between contractions • Perform timely episiotomy when indicated (not routine).

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common cause of true cephalopelvic disproportion in India?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of true cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) in India is rickets. The most common cause of true CPD in developing countries is vitamin D deficiency and rickets. 
In developed countries, it is trauma to the pelvis. It occurs due to pelvic dystocia (larger fetus and 
smaller pelvis). Relative CPD is the most common type of CPD. It is caused due to fetal malposition 
(occipitoposterior position/brow presentation).

questions.question:
Question 3: You are monitoring uterine contractions in a term primigravida in labor. You find that the 
contractions are uncoordinated and the frequency is about 8 contractions every 10 minutes. 
Which of the following is incorrect regarding your finding?

options.b: It is common in nulliparous labour
options.d: Management includes wait and watch policy

questions.explanation:
The given clinical finding is suggestive of uterine tachysystole. Oxytocin administration is not 
beneficial here as it leads to hyperstimulation of the uterus. Tachysystole (hypertonic uterine dysfunction): 212 
Sold by @itachibot • The uterine contractions are uncoordinated and increased in frequency (>5 contractions in 10 
minutes) • Contractions occur with an increase in the baseline tone without rest in between them • It is associated with late active phase dysfunction i.e., when the cervix is almost 7 cm dilated • The most common cause is occipito-posterior position. Hence, a wait and watch policy is 
adopted • It is more common in nulliparous females • Oxytocin administration leads to hyperstimulation of the uterus and is not recommended. Hypotonic uterine dysfunction: • Uterine contractions are inadequate • It is associated with early active phase • It is more common in nulliparous females.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 37-week primigravida has mild labor pains for 20 hours and the cervix is persistently 1 cm 
dilated but non-effaced. What would be the appropriate management? 205 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of either false labor pain or prolonged latent phase. The 
appropriate management is to sedate the patient and wait. False labor can be differentiated from the latent phase of labor by therapeutic rest i.e., the patient 
is sedated with morphine. Augmentation with oxytocin is done only in those patients who even after therapeutic rest 
continue to be in prolonged latent phase. There is no indication of cesarean section unless cephalopelvic disproportion is 
present. Amniotomy is not useful and should be avoided in patients with prolonged latent phase.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 34-year-old G3P2L2 woman presents to the ER with hypotension and severe abdominal 
pain. On examination, fetal parts are palpable over the abdomen. USG abdomen revealed a 
large uterine wall defect. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of uterine rupture. Maternal tachycardia is seen in this 
condition. Clinical features of uterine rupture: • Maternal tachycardia • Fetal bradycardia/absent fetal heart sounds • Hypotension • Abdominal tenderness • Palpable fetal parts on per abdomen examination • Bandl’s ring • Bleeding per vagina 213 
Sold by @itachibot • Hematuria Common causes of uterine rupture are previous caesarean delivery, myomectomy, silent rupture 
(in previous pregnancy), excess use of oxytocin, grand multipara, uterine overdistension, 
obstructed labour, difficult forceps delivery, placenta percreta

questions.question:
Question 6: A young primigravida at 36 weeks of gestation came with complaints of decreased perception 
of fetal movements for the past 2 days. NST is non-reactive and on ultrasound fetal cardiac 
activity is absent. What will be the best management in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of intrauterine fetal death (IUFD). The best management 
for such cases at 36 weeks is waiting for spontaneous expulsion. Forceps extraction is only necessary if spontaneous expulsion doesn't take place. Artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is not done due to the risk of infections. Cesarean section 
is avoided as far as possible in case of fetal death. Waiting till term is not recommended in cases of uterine infections, disseminated intravascular 
coagulation, and psychological upset.

questions.question:
Question 7: A G2P1L0 woman presents to OPD at 36 weeks of gestation for a routine visit. She mentions 
that she has a history of prior stillbirth at 37 weeks. What is the best time for delivery in this 
patient?
questions.explanation:
The best time for elective delivery in patients with a history of previous stillbirth is 39 weeks, 
either by induction or cesarean section. The recommendations for the management of subsequent pregnancy after stillbirth is as follows: • Ultrasonographic screening for fetal growth restriction after 28 weeks • Kick counts starting from 28 weeks of gestation • Antepartum fetal surveillance starting at 32 weeks or 1-2 weeks earlier than prior stillbirth • Support and reassurance Labor induction is suitable in such cases. Cesarean delivery is done for those with a 
contraindication to induction.

questions.question:
Question 8: A pregnant woman presents with obstructed labor and is grossly dehydrated. Investigations 
reveal fetal demise. What will be the management?
questions.explanation:
The best management in the given clinical scenario is cesarean section. Obstructive labor management involves administering intravenous fluids to correct dehydration, 
providing antibiotics to prevent infection, and promptly performing a cesarean section to relieve 
the obstruction. If the fetus is alive, an immediate cesarean section is typically performed. 
Management of obstructed labor never involves a wait-and-watch approach or augmenting with 
oxytocin. Clinical features of obstructed labor include maternal exhaustion, dehydration, tachycardia, 
tachypnea, genital sepsis, postpartum hemorrhage, and shock. 214 
Sold by @itachibot On P/A examination the upper uterine segment is tender and tonically contracted. The lower 
uterine segment is thin and stretched. A groove/depression is felt between the upper uterine 
segment and the lower uterine segment. This is called a Bandls ring. Complications of obstructed labor include rupture of the uterus and vesicovaginal fistula.

questions.question: Question 9: The partogram of a 28 year old G2P1 is shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
The above partogram shows a case of obstructed labour and management is caesarean section. There is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. The 
patient has adequate uterine contractions as shown. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium 
and there is fall in fetal heart rate which indicates that the baby is in distress. There is no place for wait and watch and use of oxytocin to stimulate uterine contractions in 
obstructed labor. Forceps can be applied only when the cervix is fully dilated and the head is low down.

questions.question:
Question 10: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed 
has extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is 
likely to be injured in this case? 207 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
External anal sphincter is the structure injured in an episiotomy extended posteriorly beyond the 
perineal body. Perineal tear have been divided into four degrees: • First degree- laceration is restricted to the skin of the fourchette • Second degree- muscles of the perineal body are torn through • Third degree- the tear extends partially backward through the external sphincter of the anus • Fourth degree- the external anal sphincter is torn and anal mucosa is also involved A central tear of the perineum is when the head penetrates first through the posterior vaginal 
wall, then through the perineal body and appears through the skin of the perineum. It usually 
occurs in patients with a contracted outlet.

questions.question:
Question 11: A midwife is examining a pregnant woman in labour when she noticed that the cord is 
prolapsed. What should be the next immediate step of management?

options.a: Gently replace the cord inside the vagina
options.b: Inform the doctor and shift to OT
options.d: Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.explanation:
In this scenario the midwife should put the pregnant women in a Trendelenburg position or in an 
exaggerated and elevated Sims’ position with a pillow or wedge under the hip or thigh. Caesarean section is the recommended treatment of choice for cord prolapse. Prior to performing 
the procedure, several measures can be taken to alleviate cord compression. These measures 
involve: • Manually elevating the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the entire hand through the 
vagina 215 
Sold by @itachibot • Positioning the patient in steep Trendelenburg, exaggerated Sim's position, or knee-chest 
position • Filling the bladder with 500–700 cc or more of saline (known as the Vagos method) After the diagnosis of cord prolapse is made, it is crucial not to attempt cord replacement. Such 
attempts are not only ineffective but also result in the inevitable rupture of the membranes, 
leading to cord prolapse.

questions.question:
Question 12: Abdominal examination of a 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labour, 
reveals retraction ring between the active upper segment and the distended lower segment. 
Which would best describe this ring?
questions.explanation:
Bandl's ring refers to pathological retraction ring. It is formed in cases of obstructed labour. The upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigourously in an attempt to overcome the 
obstruction while the lower segment dilates. With each contraction there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper 
segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively 
stretched and becomes thinner. The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring. 216 
Sold by @itachibot Schroeder's constriction ring is formed due to incordinate uterine action when there is localized 
spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious 
use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

questions.question:
Question 13: A 26-year-old term primigravida presents to the clinic for a regular check-up. On 
examination, uterus corresponds to term and head of the fetus is non-engaged. What is the 
most common cause for this finding?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of non-engagement at term in a primigravida is deflexed head followed 
by cephalopelvic disproportion. Non-engagement at the onset of active phase of labour is a risk factor for caesarean section. The problems of prolonged labour are that the woman is exposed to high risk of infection, ketosis 
and obstructed labour while the fetus faces the danger of asphyxia and infection. 217 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is not a cardinal movement occurring during labor?
questions.explanation:
Asynclitism is not a cardinal movement during labor. Asynclitism refers to the position of a baby in the uterus such that the head of the baby is 
presenting first and is tilted to the shoulder. This causes the fetal head to no longer be in line with 
the birth canal. Moderate degrees of asynclitism are the rule in normal labor. However, if severe, this condition is 
a common reason for cephalopelvic disproportion even with an otherwise normal sized pelvis. Asynclitism can be of 2 types: • When the sagittal suture lies anteriorly, the posterior parietal bone becomes the leading 
presenting part and is called posterior asynclitism. • When the sagittal suture lies posteriorly, the anterior parietal bone becomes the leading 
presenting part and is called anterior asynclitism.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 28-year-old primigravida is brought to the labour room in the latent phase of labor. How 
long will you wait till you declare her latent phase to be prolonged?
questions.explanation: Latent phase is said to be prolonged in a primigravida if it lasts for more than 20 hours. Friedman defined prolonged latent phase as: • A nullipara who has not entered the active phase by 20 hours after the onset of the latent phase • A multipara who has not entered the active phase by 14 hours after the onset of the latent phase

questions.question: Question 16: All of the following findings are seen in the partogram of a patient except:
questions.explanation:
The above partogram shows secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hour, arrest of descent for 
>1 hour and a fall in fetal heart rate suggestive of fetal distress. 218 
Sold by @itachibot These are characteristic findings of obstructed labour and management is caesarean section.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 26-year-old primigravida presents with labour pains. At 39 weeks of gestation, she was 
diagnosed with prolonged phase of labour. Which of the following is false regarding this 
condition?

options.c: Excessive sedation can prolong this phase

questions.explanation:
The given clinical features suggest that the patient is in latent phase of labor. Latent phase is said 
to be prolonged if it is: • >20 h in nullipara • >14 h in multipara Causes of prolonged latent phase: • Excessive sedation/epidural analgesia • Poor cervical conditions (thick, uneffaced) • False labour (most common cause in multipara) Friedman's curve is used in the diagnosis of prolonged labour. It is the sigmoid curve plotting the 
pattern of cervical dilatation during the latent and active phase of normal labour. Management includes morphine administration, rest and oxytocin stimulation.

questions.question:
Question 18: Protracted active phase dilatation in a multiparous woman is when cervical dilatation is 
 
.
questions.explanation:
Protracted active phase dilatation in a multiparous woman is when cervical dilatation is less than 
1.5 cm/hour.

questions.question: Question 19: Which among the following is false with respect to active phase of labor?

options.a: The minimum rate of cervical dilatation is 1.2cm/hr in nullipara
options.b: Arrest of dilatation is cessation of dilatation for >2 hours
options.c: Arrest of descent is cessation of descent for >1 hour
options.d: Poor cervical dilatation causes prolonged active phase

questions.explanation:
219 
Sold by @itachibot Poor cervical dilatation causes a prolonged latent phase. Arrest of cervical dilatation is defined as the lack of cervical dilatation for  2 hours during the 
active phase of labour. According to the Obstetric Care Consensus Committee, when cervical dilatation has reached  6 
cm with ruptured membranes, and there is no cervical change despite 4 hours of adequate uterine 
contractions or 6 hours of inadequate contractions, a cesarean delivery is warranted.

questions.question: Question 20: Protracted descent in labor in a nullipara is
questions.explanation: The protracted descent in labor in a nullipara is less than 1 cm/hour.

questions.question:
Question 21: A multigravida is posted for C-section due to arrest of descent in labor. It is defined as no 
descent for
questions.explanation:
Arrest of descent in labor in a multigravida is no descent for more than 1 hour. 220 
Sold by @itachibot Induction and Augmentation of Labour
